qas.question: What new venture did Marvel's founder begin after leaving the company in the 1970s?
What former Marvel title imprint did Goodman attempt to revive?
What new retail outlet came on board at the end of the 1970s to rival newsstands for comic sales?
How long was the 1970s revival of Atlas Comics in business?
During what era did newsstand distribution begin to tail off markedly for Marvel?
What company partnered with Marvel in 1974?
When was Howard the Duck launched?
What change in market distribution negatively affected Marvel near the end of the decade?
How much later were specialty comic book stores reselling titles?
The mid-1970s brought what favourable change for Marvel?

context: Goodman, now disconnected from Marvel, set up a new company called <a0_0><b5_0>Seaboard Periodicals<b5_0/><a0_0/> in 1974, reviving Marvel's old Atlas name for a new <a1_0>Atlas Comics<a1_0/> line, but this lasted only <a3_0><b8_0>a year and a half<b8_0/><a3_0/>. In <a4_0>the <b6_0>mid-1970s<b6_0/><a4_0/> a decline of the <b9_0>newsstand distribution<b9_0/> network affected Marvel. Cult hits such as Howard the Duck fell victim to the distribution problems, with some titles reporting low sales when in fact the first specialty <a2_0>comic book stores<a2_0/> resold them at a later date.[citation needed] But by the end of the decade, Marvel's fortunes were reviving, thanks to the rise of <b7_0>direct market distribution<b7_0/>—selling through those same comics-specialty stores instead of newsstands.
